text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers this morning.
RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Protectionist economic policies could hurt Poland's economy, the EU Commissioner Leon Brittan said, referring to some bad past experiences of the EU countries. Despite Poland's growing current account deficit the EU is not ready to increase import quotas for the country's agricultural products, Brittan told Reuters.

- Maintaining Poland's economic growth and implementing political programme of the ex-communist Social-Democratic Alliance (SLD) will be the tasks of the newly appointed finance minister Marek Belka, SLD said.
- Telekomunikacja Polska SA (TPSA), the state-owned telecom monopolist has announced a tender for chipcard telephone delivery worth around $150 million, TPSA said.
- Ukraine's business delegation is visting the Sieradz and Piotrkow provinces in central Poland with the hope of forming economic ties on the regional level, the delegation members said.

- Around 300 Polish and foreign firms are exhibiting their products at the Cieplo'97 energy-saving heating international fair in Gdansk-Oliwa, northern Poland. The exhibitors are presenting heating and air-condition systems, insulation materials and hea t measuring equipment.

- The first components to the F-16 multipurpose fighter aircraft produced at the Menasco Krosno plant in southeastern Poland will be exported to the U.S. in the third quarter of 1997, Menasco Krosno president Janusz Zajdel said.

- Poland's brokerage houses' turnover in January was 3.905 billion zlotys. Trading in the National Investment Fund (NFI) privatisation certificates accounted for 966.8 million zlotys and bonds for 652.9 million zlotys.
- Atlantis developer and timber processing firm is planning to issue up to five million new shares and apply for a listing on the Warsaw bourse's main market this year.
NOWA EUROPA

- Ad Novum publisher of the ex-communist Trybuna daily is seeking a domestic or foreign investor ready to finance the paper's modernisation before the coming parliamentary elections, which is seen as a possibility to increase sales, Ad Novum president Stanislaw Cwik said.
- Poland's economic activity has been slowly declining for the last three months, a report by the Warsaw School of Economics Economic Development Institute said.

- PepsiCo Poland's net profits were $1.15 billion in 1996, which showed a 28 percent decline compared with the year before. The decline was caused by the company's high restructuring costs in the fourth quarter of 1996, PepsiCo president Roger Enrico said.
GAZETA WYBORCZA
- Leading international and domestic concerns, including Coca-Cola, Procter&Gamble and Pollena Ewa have set up Poland's Pro Marka brand name protection association.

- The EU is considering antidumping customs duties aimed at Poland zinc exports to the EU countries in retaliation for the Daewoo automaker's favoured position in Poland. As the result, Polish zinc producers could lose $30 million annually, industrial sources said.
ZYCIE

- Machina Press Ltd, the Machina rock music monthly publisher considers selling the magazine, the publisher's representative Tomasz Biedrzycki said. Five companies have expressed interest in acquiring its stakes.
PARKIET
- Poland's new deputy prime minister and finance minister Marek Belka has resigned from the Jutrzenka confectionery maker's supervisory board following his cabinet appointment.
- The listed Pekpol meat producer and trader has started a new processing line in the Garwolin pork processing plant which cost 1.8 million zlotys to build.
-- Warsaw Newsroom +48 22 653 9700
